Award.AwardTitle: PENN-UPR Partnership for Research and Education
Award.AbstractNarration: This award is for the Partnership for Research & Education in Materials (PREM) between the University of Puerto Rico (UPR) (Humacao, Cayey, Bayamon, and Rio Piedras campuses) and the University of Pennsylvania (PENN) Materials Research Science & Engineering Center. Current research topics that will continue during the extension period include nano-electronics devices, simulations of electrodes and ion movement in supercapacitors, and development of electrochemical biosensors. In addition, education and outreach activities conducted with PENN will continue. The PENN-UPRH PREM has been very successful in recruiting minority students for careers in materials science. A total of 14 new PhDs have graduated from PREM students and 23 are currently in graduate programs in the USA and Puerto Rico.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vision of the UPRH-PENN PREM is diversifying science and engineering by enhancing the participation of minority men and women in materials research and education in a partnership between the University of Puerto Rico (UPR), Humacao, Cayey, and Bayamón campuses, and the University of Pennsylvania (PENN) Materials Research Science & Engineering Center (MRSEC). The intellectual merit of the UPRH-PENN PREM is a strong integration of research and education. During 2015, the award supported 9 faculty members from UPR (Cardona, Jiménez, Negrón, Pantojas, Pinto, Ramos, Sotero, Vedrine and Zimbovskaya), and 7 from PENN (Johnson A., Kikkawa, Licurse, McGhie, Mele, Santiago and Yodh). The research and education activities centered around two main topics: “Materials for Nano-electronic Devices and Sensors” and “Mathematical Modeling and Simulations of Materials”. The research productivity during this period included 4 new publications, 2 with undergraduates and High School students as co-authors, and 1 with PENN and UPR co-authors; 6 presentations were given, 4 with student co-authors.

 

The contributions of the PREM award to increase diversity in STEM are significant. During 2015, approximately 1,255 minority students, teachers, faculty, and general public participated in PREM education and outreach activities including seminars and videoconferences transmitted from PENN and the Nanodays celebration at local rural schools. In addition, approximately 6,059 visited the Nano Exhibition presented at the Arecibo Astronomical Observatory. In 2015, 17 students (HS, undergraduates, graduate) engaged in research with PREM faculty and 12 graduated (5 from high school and 7 from bachelor’s degree programs. Of the 7 BS graduates, 5 continued graduate studies (PENN State, University of South Florida (2), Florida State University and UPR-Mayaguez) in the Fall 2015.

 

The UPRH-PREM has proven how a partnership with a large research university has significantly enhanced the research and education productivity and transformed the academic environment in small, minority and undergraduate institutions. The UPRH PREM has transformed the research and education environment at UPRH. The Materials Research Shared Facilities established and managed by PREM have contributed to increase the research productivity beyond the PREM group. PREM outreach activities for K-12 students have helped attract some of the top students currently enrolled in the STEM programs at UPRH. PREM is also recognized at UPR for introducing new and innovative ways of organization and education that have been adopted by other programs and departments.
